Product of two rings is a ring.

type: {R : Type u_3} → {S : Type u_5} → [inst : Ring R] → [inst : Ring S] → Ring (R × S)
name: Prod.instRing
docString: Product of two rings is a ring.

The second component of the product of two dual numbers is equal to the sum of the product of their first components and the product of their second components.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : Semiring R] (x y : DualNumber R),
  TrivSqZeroExt.snd (x * y) = TrivSqZeroExt.fst x * TrivSqZeroExt.snd y + TrivSqZeroExt.snd x * TrivSqZeroExt.fst y
name: DualNumber.snd_mul
docString: The second component of the product of two dual numbers is equal to the sum of the product of their first components and the product of their second components.

The theorem `Finset.prod_cons` states that for any types `α` and `β`, any finite set `s` of elements of type `α`, any element `a` of type `α`, and any function `f` from `α` to `β`, where `β` is a commutative monoid, if `a` is not an element of `s`, then the product of `f x` for every `x` in the set `{a} ∪ s` (constructed by cons function) is equal to `f a` multiplied by the product of `f x` for every `x` in `s`. In mathematical terms, this theorem states that $\prod_{x \in \{a\} \cup s} f(x) = f(a) \cdot \prod_{x \in s} f(x)$.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_3} {β : Type u_4} {s : Finset α} {a : α} {f : α → β} [inst : CommMonoid β] (h : a ∉ s),
  ((Finset.cons a s h).prod fun x => f x) = f a * s.prod fun x => f x
name: Finset.prod_cons
docString: The theorem `Finset.prod_cons` states that for any types `α` and `β`, any finite set `s` of elements of type `α`, any element `a` of type `α`, and any function `f` from `α` to `β`, where `β` is a commutative monoid, if `a` is not an element of `s`, then the product of `f x` for every `x` in the set `{a} ∪ s` (constructed by cons function) is equal to `f a` multiplied by the product of `f x` for every `x` in `s`. In mathematical terms, this theorem states that $\prod_{x \in \{a\} \cup s} f(x) = f(a) \cdot \prod_{x \in s} f(x)$.

Product of two uniform isomorphisms.

type:
{α : Type u} →
  {β : Type u_1} →
    {γ : Type u_2} →
      {δ : Type u_3} →
        [inst : UniformSpace α] →
          [inst_1 : UniformSpace β] →
            [inst_2 : UniformSpace γ] → [inst_3 : UniformSpace δ] → α ≃ᵤ β → γ ≃ᵤ δ → α × γ ≃ᵤ β × δ
name: UniformEquiv.prodCongr
docString: Product of two uniform isomorphisms.

For any category with binary products, the product of two objects exists.

type:
∀ {C : Type u_2} [inst : CategoryTheory.Category.{u_1, u_2} C] [inst_1 : CategoryTheory.Limits.HasBinaryProducts C]
  (X Y : C), CategoryTheory.Limits.HasLimit (CategoryTheory.Limits.pair X Y)
name: CategoryTheory.Limits.prod.functor.proof_1
docString: For any category with binary products, the product of two objects exists.

This theorem states that if a group `G` has the property `UniqueProds`, then it also has the property `TwoUniqueProds`. In other words, in any group, if a product of elements is unique, then two such products are also unique. This is not necessarily true for semigroups that can be embedded into groups, as illustrated by Example 10.13 in J. Okniński's "Semigroup Algebras".

type: ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : UniqueProds G], TwoUniqueProds G
name: UniqueProds.toTwoUniqueProds_of_group
docString: This theorem states that if a group `G` has the property `UniqueProds`, then it also has the property `TwoUniqueProds`. In other words, in any group, if a product of elements is unique, then two such products are also unique. This is not necessarily true for semigroups that can be embedded into groups, as illustrated by Example 10.13 in J. Okniński's "Semigroup Algebras".

The product of two two-pointings.

type: {α : Type u_1} → {β : Type u_2} → TwoPointing α → TwoPointing β → TwoPointing (α × β)
name: TwoPointing.prod
docString: The product of two two-pointings.

Product of two homeomorphisms.

type:
{X : Type u_1} →
  {Y : Type u_2} →
    [inst : TopologicalSpace X] →
      [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Y] →
        {X' : Type u_4} →
          {Y' : Type u_5} →
            [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace X'] → [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace Y'] → X ≃ₜ X' → Y ≃ₜ Y' → X × Y ≃ₜ X' × Y'
name: Homeomorph.prodCongr
docString: Product of two homeomorphisms.

The prod of two morphisms is a morphism.

type:
{R : Type u} →
  {A : Type v} →
    {B : Type w} →
      {C : Type w₁} →
        [inst : Monoid R] →
          [inst_1 : NonUnitalNonAssocSemiring A] →
            [inst_2 : DistribMulAction R A] →
              [inst_3 : NonUnitalNonAssocSemiring B] →
                [inst_4 : DistribMulAction R B] →
                  [inst_5 : NonUnitalNonAssocSemiring C] →
                    [inst_6 : DistribMulAction R C] → (A →ₙₐ[R] B) → (A →ₙₐ[R] C) → A →ₙₐ[R] B × C
name: NonUnitalAlgHom.prod
docString: The prod of two morphisms is a morphism.

Product of two kernels. This is meaningful only when the kernels are s-finite.

type:
{α : Type u_1} →
  {β : Type u_2} →
    {mα : MeasurableSpace α} →
      {mβ : MeasurableSpace β} →
        {γ : Type u_4} →
          {mγ : MeasurableSpace γ} →
            ↥(ProbabilityTheory.kernel α β) → ↥(ProbabilityTheory.kernel α γ) → ↥(ProbabilityTheory.kernel α (β × γ))
name: ProbabilityTheory.kernel.prod
docString: Product of two kernels. This is meaningful only when the kernels are s-finite.

The product of two partial equivalences, as a partial equivalence on the product.

type:
{α : Type u_1} →
  {β : Type u_2} → {γ : Type u_3} → {δ : Type u_4} → PartialEquiv α β → PartialEquiv γ δ → PartialEquiv (α × γ) (β × δ)
name: PartialEquiv.prod
docString: The product of two partial equivalences, as a partial equivalence on the product.

type: Lean.TrailingParserDescr

docString: Notation for the product

The product of two finite adèles is a finite adèle.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} {K : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : IsDedekindDomain R]
  [inst_3 : Field K] [inst_4 : Algebra R K] [inst_5 : IsFractionRing R K]
  {x y : DedekindDomain.ProdAdicCompletions R K},
  DedekindDomain.ProdAdicCompletions.IsFiniteAdele x →
    DedekindDomain.ProdAdicCompletions.IsFiniteAdele y → DedekindDomain.ProdAdicCompletions.IsFiniteAdele (x * y)
name: DedekindDomain.ProdAdicCompletions.IsFiniteAdele.mul
docString: The product of two finite adèles is a finite adèle.

The coproduct cocone associated to the explicit finite coproduct.

The second projection from the product.

type: {X Y : TopCat} → TopCat.of (↑X × ↑Y) ⟶ Y

The coproduct of the cofinite filters on two types is the cofinite filter on their product.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_2} {β : Type u_3}, Filter.coprod Filter.cofinite Filter.cofinite = Filter.cofinite
name: Filter.coprod_cofinite
docString: The coproduct of the cofinite filters on two types is the cofinite filter on their product.

Expressing the product of two polynomials as a double sum.

type:
∀ {R : Type u} [inst : Semiring R] {p q : Polynomial R},
  p * q =
    Finset.sum (Polynomial.support p) fun i =>
      Polynomial.sum q fun j a => (Polynomial.monomial (i + j)) (Polynomial.coeff p i * a)
name: Polynomial.mul_eq_sum_sum
docString: Expressing the product of two polynomials as a double sum.

Product of two semirings is a semiring.

type: {R : Type u_3} → {S : Type u_5} → [inst : Semiring R] → [inst : Semiring S] → Semiring (R × S)
name: Prod.instSemiring
docString: Product of two semirings is a semiring.

The product of two dense inducings is a dense inducing

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {β : Type u_2} {γ : Type u_3} {δ : Type u_4} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace β]
  [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace γ] [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace δ] {e₁ : α → β} {e₂ : γ → δ},
  DenseInducing e₁ → DenseInducing e₂ → DenseInducing fun p => (e₁ p.1, e₂ p.2)
name: DenseInducing.prod
docString: The product of two dense inducings is a dense inducing
